thread.title: More than $121K raised for 110-year-old World War II vet to stay at home
thread.title_full: More than $121K raised for 110-year-old World War II vet to stay at home

author: FoxNews.com
title: More than $121K raised for 110-year-old World War II vet to stay at home
text:
More than $121K raised for 110-year-old World War II vet to stay at home FOX News 9 hrs ago FoxNews.com Click to expand Replay Video Watch Trump's full speech announcing SCOTUS nominee President Trump has chosen Colorado appeals court judge Neil Gorsuch as his pick for the Supreme Court. The Washington Post Trump nominates Judge Gorsuch to U.S. Supreme Court Reuters Democrats boycott Senate hearing for Mnuchin, Price Democrats boycotted a hearing of the Senate Finance Committee in which Steven Mnuchin, President Trump's nominee for Treasury secretary, and Rep. Tom Price (R-Ga.), President Trump's nominee for health and human services secretary, would have likely been approved for consideration by the full Senate, on Jan. 31 at the Capitol. The Washington Post SETTINGS OFF HD HQ SD LO More than $121G raised for 110-year-old World War II vet to stay at home FOX News See more videos SHARE SHARE TWEET SHARE EMAIL What to watch next Watch Trump's full speech announcing SCOTUS nominee The Washington Post 7:21 Trump nominates Judge Gorsuch to U.S. Supreme Court Reuters 3:08 Democrats boycott Senate hearing for Mnuchin, Price The Washington Post 2:44 Who is Steve Bannon? CNN Money 1:25 EU leader warns of Trump threat CNN 1:32 Meet Neil Gorsuch, Trump's pick for the Supreme Court The Washington Post 3:19 Nikki Haley: Iran's Ballistic Missile Test 'Absolutely Unacceptable' NBC News 1:45 State Department 'dissent channel' memo opposes travel ban FOX News 5:15 Bannon at odds on Islam, China with decades of U.S. foreign policy doctrine USA TODAY 0:53 Senate Judiciary Committee spars on Sessions's nomination The Washington Post 2:45 On frontline of Europe's 'forgotten war' BBC News 1:54 Homeland Security's Kelly: 'This is not a ban on Muslims' The Washington Post 3:03 More than $121G raised for 110-year-old World War II vet to stay at home FOX News 3:00 Iraqi PM Calls Trump Travel Ban 'an Offence to Iraq' NBC News 0:37 The Mars Rover Found a Meteorite Made of Iron NBC News 1:11 Paul Ryan: Travel ban rollout was confusing CBS News 13:51 UP NEXT A World War II veteran believed to be the oldest in the U.S. will be able to stay in his beloved Texas home for several more months thanks to the help of more than 2,500 people who raised more than $121,000.
Richard Overton, 110, has been living in his home in Austin, Texas for more than 70 years.
However, when his caretaker started experience aging issues of her own, his family feared he would need to move to an assisted living facility.
That would be a “death sentence,” according to his third cousin, Volma Overton Jr.
“We all knew that if you move Richard out of his home, he’d die,” Overton Jr. told ABC News . “That home is everything for him.”
OLDEST AMERICAN WWII VET CELEBRATES 110TH BIRTHDAY WITH A CIGAR
Overton Jr. launched a GoFundMe campaign to raise money for around-the-clock in-home care. Since its launch in December, more than $121,000 has been raised.
This meant the veteran could stay in his home for another seven months.
“His front porch is a special place,” Volma Overton, 68,” told ABC News. “He always sits there and waves to people and everyone just comes by and talks to him.”
His wife, Shirley Overton, described the elder Overton as “very witty.”
“We wanted him to be able to stay where he knows and loves,” she said. “He still walks and talks and does everything. He’s so much fun to be around.”
Overton, who was born in Bastrop County in 1906, served in the Pacific Theater from 1942 to 1945 as part of the all-black 1887th Engineer Aviation Battalion. After the war, he returned to Austin, and he has lived in the same home ever since.
His 111th birthday is in May.
Volma Overton said the money raised was used to hire an in-home senior care provider. He estimates one year of coverage will cost around $180,000.
